title.narrative: Using ICT to Provide Legal Services to Rwandan Population

description.narrative: The project targets Women, youth, People with disabilities , the unemployed, Remote and rural communities Teen mothers, generally all Rwandans but mostly focusing vulnerable population in Rwanda.

The wide use of mobile technology in Rwanda allows LAF to provide legal information and advice to vulnerable populations in Rwanda, free of charge. While the project aim at increasing access to legal aid through mobile phone engagement, the project has two phases. Phase one focused on developing the content for and promoting the use of existing 845 services within MTN and phase two consists of establishing the supplemental legal helpline at the LAF premises, the Call Centre. The project assists state and non-state legal service providers to raise citizen awareness of their rights and the laws that affect large portions of the population. This service is important to both state and non-state legal service providers, such as MAJ, Mediation Committees knon as 'Abunzi', courts and non-state legal aid providers like NGOs, and legal aid clinics of both public and private Universities. Legal aid information on LAF ICT Platform (845 service) is designed to provide various types of information including general procedural information about how to access courts, how to deal with SGBV, how to have judgments enforced, or how to file documents with the courts and aid on particular issues that service seekers may express.

This project is implemented by The Legal Aid Forum (LAF) and is funded by the Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands in Rwanda. The wide use of mobile technology in Rwanda will allow LAF to provide legal information and advice to vulnerable populations in Rwanda free of charge.

description.narrative: Rwanda has a population estimated at 11.4 million people. Women account for 52% of the population. Outside of the capital city of Kigali, the majority of the population lives in rural areas. The rural nature of the country makes access to basic services difficult. As of 2014, the average distance most people have to walk to reach basic services such as food and medical services is one hour. Literacy in Rwanda is limited. The national literacy rate for people in Rwanda aged 15 and above is 68.3%. Urban areas have higher literacy rates than rural areas, with Kigali having some of the highest literacy rates at 89% of the population aged 15 and above. However, literacy rates do vary by gender. The national literacy rate for women is 68% compared to that of men at 77%. Literacy rates are generally lower in groups with overall lower incomes. Rwanda still struggles heavily with poverty. Long-term development plans such as the Vision 2020 and Economic Development and Poverty Reduction Strategy (EDPRS) have been focused on development and poverty reduction. As of 2014, 39.1% of the total population was living below the poverty line of 159,375RWF per person per year. The Rwandan context creates a need for innovative solutions to deliver justice that are easily accessible to the most vulnerable sections of the population.

activity-description.narrative: “Using ICT to Provide Legal Services to the Rwandan Population - 845 project” is a joint partnership between Legal Aid Forum (LAF) and Viamo. The project is funded by the Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands. The project came up following a study conducted by LAF in 2017 on citizen perception of justice and legal services in Rwanda. As per the findings, the distance Rwandans have to travel to reach legal aid providers represent an access problem. This is because in Rwanda, most state and non-state legal aid services rely primarily on vis-à-vis consultations between service seeker and provider. In most cases, legal assistance and advice-seekers must travel to offices and wait for a moment to meet an advocate or a paralegal in person, regardless of the nature of the case or the services they are seeking. Out of the 5,503 respondents interviewed, 34% had to walk between 30 minutes and one hour to reach the nearest legal aid provider; 20% had to walk between one and three hours; approximately 7% had to travel more than 5 hours whereas only 4% of respondents rated their knowledge of the law as “high”. While as of March 2019, telephone penetration in Rwanda was at a rate of 77.2% and the total number of active mobile telephone subscriptions is 9,326,267; at the same time, the overall internet penetration in Rwanda is 49.5%, with 17% of the households that have access to internet at home in 2016/17; the use of Mobile phones to reach a big number of Rwandans is the best option for LAF to provide legal information, advice and legal assistance to vulnerable populations in Rwanda if it is meant to reach wide audience. In the absence of the 845 legal services, the most common idea to deliver legal aid services was that legal aid providers should set up offices closer to the communities to avoid requiring clients to walk long distances. However, building additional offices in numerous areas of the country was not feasible. Therefore, offering individuals the option of accessing legal aid services over the phone would reduce the burden on the vulnerable and indigent of having to walk long distances to receive legal. Once put in place, the 845 platform enabled all the service seekers to access legal aid services anonymously through 845/*845# free of charge. To support the project, LAF obtained funding from the Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands to Kigali and implemented the project activities.

comment.narrative: The project is designed in a way that once deemed necessary, some beneficiaries are provided legal assistance by Legal Aid Forum Lawyers or by Lawyers assigned by the Rwanda Bar Association through cases referral protocol between the Rwanda Bar Association and The legal Aid Forum.

A number of criteria and checklist was set by the LAF secretariat for a case to be treated as critical and given legal representation. An attention is paid to poor people, minors, teen mothers, detainees and victims of gender based violence.

Up to December 2020, 148 Cases were identified and handed over to lawyers for legal representation, The remaining number of callers were either satisfied and their cases were completed after being advised by the call Centre lawyers others were referred other legal aid providers like: MAJ and other institutions, Courts, Abunzi etc.

comment.narrative: Call Centre was set up to enable calls

One of the first activities under the project was the technical set up of the service and completion of the E1 set up with MTN. This E1 connection integrates a cloud-based platform with the MTN infrastructure in Rwanda. This integration pre-dated this project but is critical to the success of the project as it is the connection that is used to set up the legal aid call centre. This integration was completed in June 2018, giving partners access to a block of 1,000 MTN numbers to be used for various projects. Of these, one number was assigned as the outgoing caller ID for the call centre: +2507881260007). It is this E1 that allows subscribers to call 845 for free of charge.

title.narrative: Call center is equipped and ready

description.narrative: Call Centre enable the operators to call back citizen seeking legal advice from lawyers through call booking option. It has designed, equipped with materials including Laptops, Mobile phones, headsets, etc. in 2019, after four months of operations, data from the project advocated for taking a number of actions including expansion of the capacity of the call centre and limiting time booking was allowed in order to tackle overwhelming number of call back requests. There was a big gap between numbers of people who booked calls from those who have been called back (11%-12%). Thus, we increased the Call Center Operators from 3 to 6. As a result, all bookings are timely served without delays. In 2020 there was one additional call centre to make them 7. It is under the support of EU for the Freedom of Expression legal content.

title.narrative: Help line and call center service are advertised

description.narrative: The 845 platform is a unique and the first service of its kind in Rwanda and its’ importance have been highlighted. Therefore, it is of paramount importance to conduct awareness activities aimed at promoting the services for better and easy access to legal services. For the purposes of making the 845 legal services known by all Rwandans, the LAF have conducts promotional activities using different tools like: Promotion of the project during Legal Aid Week, Awareness Campaigns of the project countrywide, Participation in Umuganda with promotional materials for distribution, Design and distribution of project brochures, Raising awareness through interactions with the media , Radio and TV talk shows, Publication of articles in News Papers, Magazine and Newsletter and Bulk SMSs and MTN Promotion

title.narrative: Legal messages are designed, translated, updated and uploaded/linked to Viamo's 845 service

description.narrative: LAF introduced the 845 service to legal aid stakeholders in a series of meetings. The first of these was held on May 10, 2018 at Marasa Umubano Hotel to introduce the project to stakeholders and agree on the themes to be covered in this project and create thematic groups to work on the messages during the content development workshop. Five themes were agreed upon during this meeting including: 1) Gender based violence and Child’s rights, 2) Succession and Family, 3) Land and Expropriation 4) Procedural Law, 5) Jurisdiction of Courts and Abunzi Law. In January 2019 there was also development of labor related content to make the sixth theme of legal messages on 845. To develop the content, LAF consults experts from the Ministry of Justice, Office of Ombudsman, Rwanda Bar Association, Rwanda Law Reform Commission, Gender Monitoring Office and other relevant stakeholders depending on the content that is needed . After review of the messages and all corrections made, the next step is to script all messages in a dialogue format so we get content for IVR platform. When the messages are approved for recording, then it’s time for recording. After a review, then the messages are ready of pre-testing phase. In 2019, this is the process that labor related messages underwent. Before the release of the messages, LAF captured public opinion on the messages through a pre-testing phase. The purpose of the exercise was to avail legal messages without any confusion or misunderstanding by the public audience. The pretesting of labor related messages in January 2019, was conducted with collaboration with Rwanda Workers' Trade Union Confederation (CESTRAR) and its affiliated member organizations.
